body: An array keys can be `int` or `string`. Your boolean keys converted to strings.

> An array keys can be `int` or `string`. Your boolean keys converted to strings.

Sorry, I'm not sure that I understand your comment.
In the code snippet I quoted, `$key` is read from the first argument of `dropDownList`, while `$selection` is read from the model's attribute.
The keys of the array `[true => 'Yes', false => 'No']` are converted to integers by php (1 and 0). However, in the function `renderSelectOptions`, no conversion of `$selection` takes place if it is of boolean type.

I am under the impression that such a conversion would make sense here, since the conversion is also done for boolean array keys by php.

`['No', 'Yes']` converts to `[['value' => '0', 'text' => 'No'], ['value' => '1', 'text' => 'Yes']]`, prepend prompt: `[['value' => '', 'text' => 'Please select'], ['value' => '0', 'text' => 'No'], ['value' => '1', 'text' => 'Yes']]`

`(string)false` is `''` i.e. prompt value
you can use `AttributeTypecastBehavior` to normalize values

> `['No', 'Yes']` converts to `[['value' => '0', 'text' => 'No'], ['value' => '1', 'text' => 'Yes']]`, prepend prompt: `[['value' => '', 'text' => 'Please select'], ['value' => '0', 'text' => 'No'], ['value' => '1', 'text' => 'Yes']]` > > `(string)false` is `''` i.e. prompt value That does not appear to be quite correct. In your explanation, `$key` and `$selection` are mixed up. Let me try to make it more clear: When I call `dropDownList([true => 'Yes', false => 'No'], ['prompt' => 'Please select'])`, it is the same as if I had called `dropDownList([1 => 'Yes', 0 => 'No'], ['prompt' => 'Please select'])`, because php immediately does the conversion of array keys. The cast `(string) false` therefore never occurs. Here, https://github.com/yiisoft/yii2/blob/2874e070f3ad88c727b1335ba4f4515855bf5f64/framework/helpers/BaseHtml.php#L1914 the `$key` is cast to a string, which yields `'0'` and that is fine. After this line, `$attrs = [ 'value' => 1, 'selected' => false ]`. And updating `'selected'` fails, because this comparison fails: https://github.com/yiisoft/yii2/blob/2874e070f3ad88c727b1335ba4f4515855bf5f64/framework/helpers/BaseHtml.php#L1917 Since `$key` (being the integer 0) and `$selection` (being the boolean false) do not compare to equal with `strcmp`, which makes sense of course. At the end of the function, the `$lines` array contains ```php $lines = [ '

@adnandautovic 
> (string)false is '' i.e. prompt value

I mean your boolean attribute converts to string value, `(string)null` is too `''`
https://github.com/yiisoft/yii2/blob/2874e070f3ad88c727b1335ba4f4515855bf5f64/framework/helpers/BaseHtml.php#L1875

in this case `ActiveField::checkbox()` looks more appropriate

> I mean your boolean attribute converts to string value, `(string)null` is too `''`

Actually, it does not:
https://github.com/yiisoft/yii2/blob/2874e070f3ad88c727b1335ba4f4515855bf5f64/framework/helpers/BaseHtml.php#L1874-L1876

`$selection` is not traversable, since it is not an array, but a boolean.

> in this case `ActiveField::checkbox()` looks more appropriate

Unfortunately, this does not work. The model represents a filter and there are three possible selections: `None` (display all), `Yes` (display only things where condition is true) and `No` (display only things where condition is false).

@adnandautovic you right, but prompt is first option in list i.e. selected by default (when `$selected` is null).
your bool attribute in any case converts to string in `!strcmp($key, $selection)`

@WinterSilence The normalization takes place in the model's `rules`, where casting to bool takes place (since the underlying GET request does not pass a true boolean to php).

Anyway, the fix you suggested would also be quite fine. I just think the `!` is misplaced and it should read as follows instead (`strcmp` returns 0 if it thinks the values are equal):
```php
 $attrs['selected'] = $selection !== null &&
      (!ArrayHelper::isTraversable($selection) && ($strict ? $selection == $key : !strcmp($key, $selection))
      || ArrayHelper::isTraversable($selection) && ArrayHelper::isIn((string)$key, $selection, $strict));
```

> The normalization takes place in the model's rules, where casting to bool takes place (since the underlying GET request does not pass a true boolean to php).

value converts to bool when you load request data. also you can declare attribute setter/getter to convert value.

rename.from: ActiveForm dropDownList does not set the default selection propery if the underlying model's attribute is of boolean type
rename.to: ActiveForm dropDownList does not set the selected option properly if the underlying model's attribute is of boolean type

body: I just realized I had given the issue a misleading name. The problem was not incorrect setting of the default value (`'Please select'`), but incorrect setting of the selected value (`'Yes'`) or (`'No'`).

issue.title: 19324 dropdownlist selection for boolean attributes

repository.name: yii2
repository.description: Yii 2: The Fast, Secure and Professional PHP Framework

issue.body:
| Q             | A
| ------------- | ---
| Is bugfix?    | ✔️
| New feature?  | ❌
| Breaks BC?    | ❌
| Fixed issues  | #19324

@WinterSilence Just one question about the order of `$strict`: Should the comparison with `==` really be the strict one? Comparing with `strcmp` appears more strict to me, but for now I implemented your original suggestion. What do you think?

body: ...or use checkbox input as all normal developers :)
